div1.p:
Your kind words about my poem in Harper's Weekly was very heartening. I value them the more since they are the utterance of one who is himself a poet — whose work, male, dynamic and salient, I have long admired. Your lyre is a bard's lyre — no
tinkling minor poet's mandolin.

The first book of yours I read was lent me by my friend Phyllis Partington of California. It was a pleasant and peculiar coincidence that the same post which brought me your letter bore one for my wife — from "Mrs Bellman" of your city, accepting two poems of hers. Neither of us had ever received letters from Minneapolis before. Perhaps you may have noticed her work
43
in some of the English and American magazines. She is one of England's youngest and most gifted poets.
Your mention of Yorse recalls to my mind what he told me some time ago that no English or American magazine was edited by an accredited man of letters!
"The Lyric Year" is the more futile and unrepresentative for not having something of yours. My own poem they butchered horribly in the composition.

It is a few minutes of midnight — Christmas night. So here is wishing you a joyous one and a New Year pregnant with poetry — actual and transcribed. With many
45
Thanks and Greetings,
